messages.text:
While things are never and will never (exceptions aside) be deleted from registry at some point we might have the option to `unlist` them s that they don’t tab-complete, and maybe don’t block the name from being used for something else, and maybe show a warning on install.

<https://github.com/JuliaLang/Pkg.jl/issues/2194>

root.text: I'm working on an experimental package that may ultimately be absorbed into another package. Is that a good reason to not register it? Are outdated packages ever removed from the registry? I'd like to avoid potentially confusing users if there are two packages with similar names but one is discontinued.

elements.text: I'm working on an experimental package that may ultimately be absorbed into another package. Is that a good reason to not register it? Are outdated packages ever removed from the registry? I'd like to avoid potentially confusing users if there are two packages with similar names but one is discontinued.
While things are never and will never (exceptions aside) be deleted from registry at some point we might have the option to
unlist
them s that they don’t tab-complete, and maybe don’t block the name from being used for something else, and maybe show a warning on install.

messages.text: Re- <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/funding-community-projects/56288/2|https://discourse.julialang.org/t/funding-community-projects/56288/2>, someone should submit a proposal to tackle the RegistryCI issue backlog / add more <#CED4U82BC|pkg-trust> checks etc! The General registry is vital infrastructure and could use more help to stay healthy as the ecosystem grows, imo. (I’d submit one but I don’t have enough time to do the project!)

attachments.title: Funding Community Projects
attachments.text: Hi fellow Julians! Many of you probably know that the Julia project uses the NumFOCUS, an US non-profit organisation as it’s fiscal sponsor. This means that income for the project is collected in accounts of that organisation, and our expenses are paid though there. The primary source of income is via sponsorship of JuliaCon, although individual sponsorships are now significant as well. Major expenses are again for JuliaCon, as well for our summer-of-code projects. As a result of careful stewa...

What do you mean with this. All packages are accepted if they pass the automatic checks. These automatic checks does not involve there being code in the package (maybe they should). But I don't see how PkgTemplates is relevant to this?

messages.text: Sorry, I don't know how the automatic checks work, and I thought they check for the minimal structure, and using that package, you get that minimal structure from the beginning, even with an empty module in src. But it seems that I have just interpreted correlation as causation. In any case, it sounds sensible to check for the content of the package module. Here there is another example: <https://github.com/Humans-of-Julia/ModernGraphs.jl/blob/main/src/ModernGraphs.jl>

messages.text:
Hey everyone, I'm trying to clean up the permissions in the JuliaRegistries organization. I've been organizing the repos into teams, and then putting people on teams. Unfortunately, when you add someone to a team, GitHub likes to automatically "watch" all of those repos. So if you are a JuliaRegistries member, you may find that you have suddenly been "subscribed" to multiple JuliaRegistries repos that you weren't previously watching.

Unfortunately you will need to manually click "unwatch" from any repo that you don't want to subscribe to.

Sorry about this inconvenience! I don't know of any way that I can disable this in GitHub.

elements.text:
Hey everyone, I'm trying to clean up the permissions in the JuliaRegistries organization. I've been organizing the repos into teams, and then putting people on teams. Unfortunately, when you add someone to a team, GitHub likes to automatically "watch" all of those repos. So if you are a JuliaRegistries member, you may find that you have suddenly been "subscribed" to multiple JuliaRegistries repos that you weren't previously watching.

Unfortunately you will need to manually click "unwatch" from any repo that you don't want to subscribe to.

Sorry about this inconvenience! I don't know of any way that I can disable this in GitHub.

messages.text:
currently RegistryCI parses the github status to see if automerge has passed and to therefore merge the PR: <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/RegistryCI.jl/blob/c8c16ff6da9e4bb84bb69b982501eb5a88ffe2bf/src/AutoMerge/cron.jl#L131-L132>. What if instead of using github statuses, AutoMerge adds a label “AutoMerge passed” or such, and then the cron job checks the label instead of the github status?

The advantage would be we could add that label manually so we don’t need the “needs manual merge in 3 days” label (and for someone to follow up).

This wouldn’t be a perfect solution, because if two things were blocking it (like a compat issue + a naming issue), then the human moderator shouldn’t add the “AutoMerge: passed” label (until e.g. the combat issue is resolved).

elements.text: currently RegistryCI parses the github status to see if automerge has passed and to therefore merge the PR:

. What if instead of using github statuses, AutoMerge adds a label “AutoMerge passed” or such, and then the cron job checks the label instead of the github status?

The advantage would be we could add that label manually so we don’t need the “needs manual merge in 3 days” label (and for someone to follow up).

This wouldn’t be a perfect solution, because if two things were blocking it (like a compat issue + a naming issue), then the human moderator shouldn’t add the “AutoMerge: passed” label (until e.g. the combat issue is resolved).

messages.text:
> s the JuliaRegistry willing to accept packages with a BSD license with an added restriction on commercialization?
I assume it's a no?

elements.text: s the JuliaRegistry willing to accept packages with a BSD license with an added restriction on commercialization?
I assume it's a no?

messages.text: Yeah we only accept packages with an OSI-approved license.

elements.text: Yeah we only accept packages with an OSI-approved license.

messages.text: What package is this for?

elements.text: What package is this for?

messages.text: <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/31549#issuecomment-796331793> the original one :smile:

elements.text: the original one

messages.text: Yeah, any license with "added restriction on commercialization" violates one or more of the components of the open source definition (<https://opensource.org/docs/osd>)

elements.text: Yeah, any license with "added restriction on commercialization" violates one or more of the components of the open source definition (

messages.text: There are several OSI-approved BSD licenses: <https://opensource.org/licenses/alphabetical>

elements.text: There are several OSI-approved BSD licenses:

messages.text: They could use any of those

elements.text: They could use any of those

messages.text: But I don't think any of those includes the commercialization restriction that they want

elements.text: But I don't think any of those includes the commercialization restriction that they want

messages.text: For example, Pumas.jl has a non-commercial restriction in its license, and as a result it is not registered in the General registry

elements.text: For example, Pumas.jl has a non-commercial restriction in its license, and as a result it is not registered in the General registry

messages.text: There are OSI approved licenses with copy-left which restrict commercialization. Not all OSI-approved licenses are permissive. It is recommended to avoid those but it is allowed by the OSI-approved requirement.

elements.text: There are OSI approved licenses with copy-left which restrict commercialization. Not all OSI-approved licenses are permissive. It is recommended to avoid those but it is allowed by the OSI-approved requirement.

messages.text: You mean like GPL and AGPL?

elements.text: You mean like GPL and AGPL?

messages.text: Those would be perfectly fine. I'll suggest those in the thread.

elements.text: Those would be perfectly fine. I'll suggest those in the thread.

messages.text: What goes against the OSI principles is exclusion (e.g., this software can’t be use for warfare applications or genocide). In general, exclusions happen through export control national laws (US has trade embargos and such).

elements.text: What goes against the OSI principles is exclusion (e.g., this software can’t be use for warfare applications or genocide). In general, exclusions happen through export control national laws (US has trade embargos and such).

messages.text: I've suggested those in that thread.

elements.text: I've suggested those in that thread.

messages.text: I suggested GPL and AGPL. Are there any others that you would suggest?

elements.text: I suggested GPL and AGPL. Are there any others that you would suggest?

messages.text: Those are usually the most common copyleft licenses.

elements.text: Those are usually the most common copyleft licenses.

messages.text: GPL allows commercialisation :thinking_face:

elements.text: GPL allows commercialisation

messages.text: Yeah but if you distribute your software commercially, you have to also distribute the source? IIUC. (I am not a lawyer, this is not legal advice.)

elements.text: Yeah but if you distribute your software commercially, you have to also distribute the source? IIUC. (I am not a lawyer, this is not legal advice.)

messages.text: yes, but you can still commercialise it

elements.text: yes, but you can still commercialise it

messages.text: True. Do the authors of this package need to prevent all commercialization?

elements.text: True. Do the authors of this package need to prevent all commercialization?

messages.text: Idk of any way to prevent all commercial uses while still being OSI-compliant.

elements.text: Idk of any way to prevent all commercial uses while still being OSI-compliant.

messages.text: I mean no major license bans commercialization in all forms as most commercialization happens through software as service which is not well captured in the current license framework. Is a hot topic on the EU (especially with the controversies of first seller).

messages.text: <@UCZ7VBGUD> It seems that if the "Pkg.add" check fails, then an error gets thrown during the "OSI license" check, and AutoMerge exits with an error without posting an AutoMerge comment. For example, see this PR: <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/31753>

elements.text: It seems that if the "Pkg.add" check fails, then an error gets thrown during the "OSI license" check, and AutoMerge exits with an error without posting an AutoMerge comment. For example, see this PR:

messages.text: It is a bit annoying that automatic merging of patch releases for packages suddenly stopped working because of the license check. I have deadlines and wanted to do version bumps as usual, but it suddenly became much more work which was not anticipated.

elements.text: It is a bit annoying that automatic merging of patch releases for packages suddenly stopped working because of the license check. I have deadlines and wanted to do version bumps as usual, but it suddenly became much more work which was not anticipated.

messages.text:
I think if this is an issue, it is reasonable to ask for a manual merge while you work it out, with a promise that you will sort it out within e.g. 2 weeks.
Esp if the question is not "open source y/n?" but "which license?"

root.text: It is a bit annoying that automatic merging of patch releases for packages suddenly stopped working because of the license check. I have deadlines and wanted to do version bumps as usual, but it suddenly became much more work which was not anticipated.

elements.text: It is a bit annoying that automatic merging of patch releases for packages suddenly stopped working because of the license check. I have deadlines and wanted to do version bumps as usual, but it suddenly became much more work which was not anticipated.

I think if this is an issue, it is reasonable to ask for a manual merge while you work it out, with a promise that you will sort it out within e.g. 2 weeks.
Esp if the question is not "open source y/n?" but "which license?"

messages.text: quick question: i tried to registrate my new package using Registrator.jl. I read somewhere I should have gotten an automatic robot-response but I didn't. Is that normal, can anyone help?

elements.text: quick question: i tried to registrate my new package using Registrator.jl. I read somewhere I should have gotten an automatic robot-response but I didn't. Is that normal, can anyone help?

messages.text: Yes, you should. The first checklist question is whether you have installed Registrator for your repository. It would also help with a pointer to your repository and the attempt to perform the registration.

elements.text: Yes, you should. The first checklist question is whether you have installed Registrator for your repository. It would also help with a pointer to your repository and the attempt to perform the registration.
